description.narrative: The Pankisi Gorge has obtained an international reputation for members of its population to travel to Syria or Iraq as foreign fighters. To this day there are still reports coming in that IS fighters from Georgia, from both the Pankisi Gorge region or Adjaran Eco-Migrant community, have died abroad. To reduce the amount of foreign fighters produced in these regions, the donor community has set up projects in the Pankisi and Adjaran communities to improve the living situation. However, many of these projects are based on assumption of what these communities might need, rather than on research done for and about these communities. And these projects focus on improving the situation by improving the output rather than dealing with the problems at their stem. The goal of this project is to reveal the factors leading to radicalization. This will be done by comparing the Pankisi Gorge and the Adjaran Eco-Migrant communities to two other regions that are also Muslim but do not produce foreign fighters. The comparative study will also reveal areas where there is still room for donor activities in the future. This project will be conducted by a highly professional research center, with experience in doing research in Georgia and both the Adjaran and Pankisian communities. The research will be conducted based on a specially developed methodology that reveals the factors that can lead to radicalization and can be used to counter violent extremism. The results will be used to promote the implementation of more effective, evidence-based policies and programs to counter radicalization in Georgia, and to encourage more useful government-provided social services that target issues still left unaddressed. The end users will be the local NGOs in Tbilisi and across Georgia, the government of Georgia and the donors whom can then target the most pressing needs of the communities and counter violent extremism. The ultimate beneficiaries of the project will be the residents of the Pankisi Gorge and the Adjaran eco-migrant communities who will benefit from the problem targeted aid. This study will fill this gap by carrying out comparative research in two community types that have lost members – Adjaran eco-migrant communities and the Pankisi Gorge – to two communities that are very similar, but have not lost members to conflict – other Adjaran ecomigrant communities and the Daghestani villages on the border with the Russian Federation. As the needs of the communities are being revealed during this study, the CRRC would like to cooperate with an NGO to address a key point issue uncovered by this study. We may consider funding this project in the future from the Accountability Fund.
